bestBHT.bht: Jesus, looking at them all, instructed the man with the withered hand to stretch it forth. In obedience to Jesus' command, the man stretched out his hand, fully extending it. Through this act of faith, his hand was completely restored, just as it was before.

Marvin Vincent: Thy hand. The arm was not withered.
Archibald T. Robertson: He looked round about on them all (περιβλεψαμενος). First aorist middle participle as in Mark 3:5, the middle voice giving a personal touch to it all."
Stretch forth thy hand (εξτεινον την χειρα σου). First aorist active imperative. Stretch out , clean out, full length.

All three Gospels also have the first aorist passive indicative απεκατεσταθη with the double augment of the double compound verb αποκαθιστημ. As in Greek writers, so here the double compound means complete restoration to the former state.
John Gill: Stretch forth thy hand, and he did so; he stretched it out, as the Syriac and Persic versions render it, which he was not able to do before.
And certain it is, that his withered hand was restored sound and well as the other, directly.

His hand was restored well as the other; the phrase, 'well as the other', is left out in one copy, and in the Vulgate Latin version; and so is the word 'well' in the Syriac and Arabic versions; and the word 'immediately' is added in the Ethiopic version.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus looked around at the people, his eyes filled with compassion. He commanded the man with the withered hand to stretch it out, to fully extend it. In an instant, complete restoration came upon the man as his hand became whole, just like the other one. The withered hand was no more, and the man experienced the immediate healing power of Jesus.

Jesus, looking at them all, instructed the man with the withered hand to stretch it forth. In obedience to Jesus' command, the man stretched out his hand, fully extending it. Through this act of faith, his hand was completely restored, just as it was before.

The man with the withered hand stood before Jesus, and Jesus looked around at all the people. Then He commanded the man, Stretch forth thy hand, and the man obeyed, stretching it out fully. In all three Gospels, it is emphasized that the man's hand was completely restored to its former state, just like the other hand. It is clear that the man's hand was instantly and fully healed, able to function just as it did before.

The man with the withered hand stood before Jesus, and Jesus looked around at all the people, taking a personal approach. He then commanded the man, Stretch forth thy hand, instructing him to extend it fully. In all three Gospels, it is noted that the man's hand was restored completely to its former state, just like the other hand. The significance of this restoration is that the man's hand was immediately and fully healed, able to function in the same way it did before.

Jesus, after looking around at everyone, told the man with the withered hand to Stretch forth thy hand, and the man obediently extended it fully. It is noteworthy that all three Gospels emphasize the complete restoration of the man's hand to its former state, just like the other hand. This restoration is significant because it resulted in an immediate and full healing, enabling the man's hand to function just as it did before.
